div1.p: Thank you for the kind and thoughtful response to the letter I sent you last April.

So you won't be mistaken, let me say I received your letter last June; but only now have I collected some thoughts into readable form. Although by calendar standards our last correspondence was sometime back, my thoughts of you are fresh — you never seem far away or long ago as people sometimes do.

I appreciated the note in your letter of June 14th that All Is But a Beginning would be out on September 20th. I requested the book from a somewhat puzzled bookstore proprietor only hours after it had arrived at the store and well before it had reached the shelves!

I enjoyed the book immensely, being one of those who "loves you just a little," if not more. It was a thrill to relive

with you those glorious episodes of youth with the accompanying bold emotions. Though you mention in the epilogue the "snow-topped summit" of your years, the wonderful spirit of youth has not faded from you even a years worth. The years seem only to bring you an ever-broadening enthusiasm and a deeper appreciation of this phenomenon of LIFE.
Accordingly, All Is But a Beginning is full of LIFE — certainly not just life restricted to the days and events of your youth, but LIFE the timeless adventure, the total exhilerating experience.

I was especially excited by the lyric "The Ghostly Brother", which I had not read before. The mood of the poem is haunting, almost frightening; yet the theme is, curiously, appealing. The lyric focuses on that spiritual condition inherent in all of your works, which is felt, though not necessarily expressed. I foudn the poem very moving and meaningful.

All Is But a Beginning was a delightful and invaluable experience for me, as have been the many other works by you I have read. I cherish the beautiful sensitivity expressed on the pages of your books and am happy to share with one so very much aware the "wonder of it all."
I trust you are nearing completion of the adult portion of your autobiography I have been anxiously looking for it in the book reviews and on the shelves of the bookstore.
You asked in your letter if I had seen you on the Dick Cavett Show. I regret to say I have missed both times the Cavett show with you has been on television. I can only hope it is shown once more.
Please write me again when you have time. Take care of yourself.
